In the pig-iron trade it is reported that there were more blast furnaces in operation at the end of January than at the corresponding date last year and the extent of recovery which took place in this industry during the month may be judged from the fact that the percentage of unemployment has fallen from 44-7 to 20'3. The improvement in the iron and steel trades was also of a substantial nature, and it is reported that in most areas there is still a considerable amount of work in hand, part of which, no doubt, represents orders accumulated during the coal-mining dispute. The further recovery in shipbuilding, which was made possible by the increasing availability of constructional material, was most marked on the North-East Coast, Scotland and Wales. In the first two areas, however, the depression remained acute, approximately 50 per - cent, on the North-East Coast and 40 per cent, in Scotland of shipbuilding workers remaining unemployed. In engineering the improvement which took place was confined mostly to general and marine engineering, and the volume of unemploy-ment in this industry still remained very high. In one area only Scotland is the employment position in engineering better than it was a year ago.The decreased unemployment in the cotton industry was shared by all departments. In the Egyptian spinning section the employment position is stated to be satisfactory, but in the American section there is still an appreciable amount of short-time working and under-employment.As regards the position in coal mining, It will be observed from the above table that the number of miners recorded as unemployed on the 24th January is considerably greater than on the 20th December. It must be remembered, however, that the December figures exclude a very much greater proportion of miners disqualified under the Trade Dispute disqualification than the January figures. According to the returns received by the Mines Department, the volume of employment in coal mining was considerably greater in January than in the previous month. In some areas, however, notably Wales and Durham, the percentage of unemployment in coal mining is still very high. The increase in unemployment in the woollen and worsted industries, and which was also apparent in a lesser degree in the silk, hosiery, bleaching and dyeing industries, was largely of a seasonal nature. The usual New Year slackness must also be held responsible for the relapse in the distributive trades, wdiile the increase in unemployment in the building industry must also be largely attributed to the seasonal causes.(D.) Latest Figures.The latest figure of unemployment published is that for the 14th February, giving the total number on the registers as 1,270,200. This is a decrease over the position on the 31st January amounting to 61,343, and an increase over a . year ago of 130,972.ARTHUR STEEL-MAITLAND.Ministry of Labour,February 25, 1927.
